awd_titl_txt: RUI:  COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Surface reservoir ages and ventilation in the Bering Sea during the last deglaciation from tephras and radiocarbon
awd_abstract_narration:
Radiocarbon estimates of the past ocean are valuable because they have the potential to trace the distribution and transport of water masses, which are both important for understanding the role of ocean circulation in climate changes. A well-known problem with radiocarbon reconstructions from paired measurements of benthic and planktonic foraminifera is that most studies assume that the offset between the apparent radiocarbon age of the local surface water and the contemporary atmosphere (the "surface reservoir age") has been constant through time. Modeling simulations show that surface reservoir age probably changed by hundreds of years at centennial to millennial timescales in the past. Unaccounted-for changes in surface reservoir age are problematic, since they can introduce as large a signal into a radiocarbon reconstruction of the ocean interior as the changes associated with ocean circulation. In this collaborative project, the research team will match volcanic ash layers (tephras) from marine sediment cores in the southeast Bering Sea to independently-dated tephras from nearby Sanak Island. This will allow reconstruction of surface reservoir ages from this location and testing of the hypothesis that reservoir age varied by hundreds of years in the past. The team will also be able to re-evaluate the conclusions of studies based on foraminiferal radiocarbon where the authors assumed constant surface reservoir age, including the hypothesis that North Pacific intermediate water ventilation was antiphase with the North Atlantic during the last deglaciation. The results of this study have potential impact across disciplines, including improving the dating of archaeological remains from the earliest humans in the eastern Aleutians, and the understanding of the timing of waves of migration with ecological and climatic changes from that time period. Funding also supports research experiences for undergraduates from Williams College (an RUI institution).
 
More specifically, the recently published tephrochronology from the last 17 ky from Sanak Island in the eastern Aleutians (Misarti et al. 2012) presents a new and unique opportunity to reconstruct surface reservoir ages and ventilation from the subarctic Pacific, since Sanak Island is near the Umnak Plateau in the southeast Bering Sea, which has been cored for high-resolution paleoceanographic work. The research team will measure major and trace element abundance with electron microprobe and laser-ablation-inductively-coupled-plasma mass spectrometry to match tephras between Sanak Island and three nearby marine sediment cores spanning 1 to 2 km water depth, creating tephra-based age models for the cores. They will then measure a time series of planktonic radiocarbon in the sediment cores to produce a record of local surface reservoir age changes from the SE Bering Sea. They will measure benthic radiocarbon at the same resolution and use the tephra-based age model to calculate the Delta14C of the water column at 1 to 2 km in the Bering Sea. With this reconstruction, the team will be able to evaluate proposed changes in North Pacific circulation and Bering Sea ventilation from the last deglaciation, and constrain the end-member properties of North Pacific water masses from the past.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to study the patterns in ocean circulation in the Bering Sea during the last deglaciation, which was the transition between the last ice age and the current warm interglacial 20,000 to 10,000 years ago. The tools we used were the chemistry of volcanic glass from ash layers and radiocarbon measurements of benthic and planktonic foraminifera, which live in the surface ocean and on the seafloor and record the chemistry of seawater in their shells. Key questions included (1) can we develop a robust age-depth relationship in marine sediment cores by correlating the ash layers to ash layers in the lake cores? (2) how much did the radiocarbon age difference between the surface ocean and the atmosphere vary during the deglaciation? (3) how did the radiocarbon distribution in the ocean evolve during the deglaciation? (4) what do the radiocarbon data suggest about how the ocean circulation in this region changed, and its role in global climate change and atmospheric carbon dioxide rise?

Fourteen undergraduate students at Williams College contributed to this project. We measured the major and trace element chemistry of ash layers in lake sediment cores and nearby marine sediment cores to fingerprint individual volcanic eruptions and match ash layers between cores. We measured radiocarbon ages of planktonic and benthic foraminifera in the marine sediment cores. Due to the pandemic, the radiocarbon ages in the lake cores have not yet been measured. When it is safe to travel, we will collect the samples and make these measurements in order to complete the project.

We have analyzed the chemistry of over 100 tephra layers from the marine and lake cores, and found around half have discrete clustered chemistries and half show linear variation consistent with magmatic evolution during eruption. In samples with linear variation, we have found that some incompatible trace element ratios can be diagnostic of particular eruptions because they remain constant even across a wide range of element concentrations. This allowed us to find more tephra matches than were possible using solely clustered tephra compositions. Our first estimates of the radiocarbon age difference between the surface/deep ocean and atmosphere suggest that during the mid-deglaciation, values are similar to the preindustrial ocean. When we are able to further refine the lake sediment core radiocarbon measurements, we will be able to expand our reconstructions across more time periods of interest.

The undergraduate students who participated in this project designed projects, prepared samples, traveled to external labs to collect data, interacted with collaborators and their research groups, and presented their findings at professional conferences. We strived to recruit a diversity of students from all class years to contribute the project, guide them in developing research, technical and communication skills, and provide an opportunity for them to get immersed in an ocean and earth science problem that they could connect to modern global climate change. The students included seven women and one non-binary person. Nine of the students identify as people of color and/or are first in their family to go to college. Three students completed senior honors theses and four completed independent research projects for course credit. Three are now enrolled in PhD programs in Earth/Ocean science, and another is enrolled in a PhD program in Science and Technology Studies with a focus on climate change.
